conversations.content: In southern Grastaea, legends speak of miraculous springs deep in the mountains—including one that can bring a person back from the brink of death itself.
Near that spring lived a dragon who took the shape of a beautiful woman, though none knew for certain what her true form was. One day, there came a group of mercenaries.
Their commander carried in his arms a fighter—his son—who had been badly wounded in combat. The commander then begged the woman to use the spring to save his son's life.
When the dragon refused, the man was incredulous. ＂All manner of beasts heal themselves in this spring! Do you claim that the life of my son is worth less than an animal's?!＂
＂It is not a question of worth, but of purity,＂ replied the dragon. ＂You and your son killed scores for naught but coin. Yet when animals kill, they do so only to survive.＂
Her words enraged the commander. ＂We may kill for coin, but we need that coin to live! It is no different from your beloved animals!＂
The commander drew his blade and slashed the dragon's throat, then lay his son in the spring—but nothing happened. For it only worked miracles at the behest of the dragon.
There, beside the reddened spring, the commander learned his son's fate had been decided long before they had even arrived.
Laying his son in the spring did not heal his wounds or stop his bleeding, for the water's mana was lost when the commander killed the dragon in his rage.
Before long, his son drew his last breath. Overcome with grief, the commander bade his men gather firewood with which to burn the remains.
The commander lay the dragon's body beside his son's and mourned, filled with belated fear and sorrow for slaughtering the dragon.
When they burned her body, the corpse rose up among the flames and unfurled a great pair of wings. The dragon looked toward the terrified commander as she spoke.
＂At this very moment, a child has been born in a distant land. He is your son, reincarnated.＂
＂Though you will never see this child in your lifetime, your son's soul yet lives upon this earth. Rejoice.＂
Her words made the commander realize that, while his son's body could not be saved, at least his soul had been spared. And so he wept, and was glad for it.
That dragon was called Phoenix. If she is killed, she will rise from the flames to live again. Her flesh may be temporary, but her soul is eternal. As it is with her, so it is with all.
